oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title> <jats:p>The Asian cyprinid <jats:italic>Pseudorasbora parva</jats:italic> is considered to be a major threat to native fish communities and listed as an invasive alien species of European Union concern. Our study aims to gain evidence-based knowledge on the impact of both <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic> and its parasite <jats:italic>Sphaerothecum destruens</jats:italic> on native fish populations by analysing fish assemblages and body condition of individuals of native fish species in floodplain water bodies that were invaded and uninvaded by <jats:italic>P</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>parva</jats:italic>. We explored the use of environmental DNA (eDNA) techniques to detect <jats:italic>S. destruens</jats:italic>. Prevalence of <jats:italic>S. destruens</jats:italic> in native fish species was assessed. Fish samplings showed significantly negative correlations between the abundance of <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic> and the native <jats:italic>Leucaspius delineatus</jats:italic>, and <jats:italic>Pungitius pungitius</jats:italic> and three biodiversity indices of the fish assemblages (Simpson’s diversity index, Shannon–Wiener index and evenness). Contrastingly, the abundances of the native <jats:italic>Gasterosteus aculeatus</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic> were positively related. In nearly all isolated water bodies with <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic>, this species is outnumbering native fish species. No effect of <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic> presence was found on body condition of native fish species. <jats:italic>Sphaerothecum destruens</jats:italic> was demonstrated to occur in both <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>G. aculeatus</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>Gasterosteus aculeatus</jats:italic> is suggested to be an asymptomatic carrier that can aid the further spread of <jats:italic>S. destruens.</jats:italic> Analysis of eDNA proved to be a promising method for early detection of <jats:italic>S. destruens</jats:italic>, here showing that <jats:italic>S. destruens</jats:italic> presence coincided with <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic> presence. The ongoing invasion of both <jats:italic>P. parva</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>S. destruens</jats:italic> is predicted to pose a significant risk to native fish communities. </jats:p>
